Yes, here's an example of the checklist in the form of a table: | Characteristic | Questions to consider | | --- | --- | | Location | - Is the property located in a remote area or an area with limited access?
- Does the property have unique environmental or geographical features, such as being situated on a hillside, near a body of water, or in a densely wooded area?
- Is the property located in an area with a high crime rate or environmental hazards?
- Does the property have a unique or challenging street layout, such as a cul-de-sac or a property with a steep driveway? | | Property type and design | - Does the property have an unusual or complex design, such as a multi-unit building, a property with multiple levels, or a property with an attached garage?
- Does the property have unique or special features, such as a swimming pool, a hot tub, or a large deck?
- Does the property have an unusual or complex heating and cooling system, such as a geothermal or radiant heat system?
- Does the property have any outbuildings, such as a barn, shed, or guesthouse? | | Age and condition | - Is the property significantly older or newer than the typical properties in the area?
- Does the property require extensive repairs or renovations?
- Does the property have any significant or unusual wear and tear, such as extensive water damage or evidence of pest infestation?
- Has the property been significantly altered, such as being converted from a single-family home to a multi-unit building, or having additions or alterations made to the original structure? | | Zoning and land use | - Does the property have unique zoning or land use restrictions, such as being located in a floodplain, a conservation area, or a designated historic district?
- Is the property located in an area with complex land use regulations or restrictions, such as a neighborhood with strict homeowner association rules or a property located in a wetlands area?
- Does the property have any zoning variances or conditional use permits that affect its value or usability? | | Market conditions | - Is the property located in an area with rapidly appreciating or declining markets?
- Does the property's market have unique economic or demographic characteristics, such as a large number of vacation homes or a significant number of high-end properties?
- Does the property's market have any unusual economic or demographic trends, such as a high level of unemployment or a large number of foreclosures?
- Does the property's market have any unique or challenging supply and demand factors, such as a limited number of available properties or a high demand for properties with certain features or amenities? |
Can you help me define a purpose for this information?

Certainly! The purpose of this information is to help your team determine whether an appraisal order is complex and whether a higher fee is justified. By using this checklist, your team will be able to consistently and objectively assess the characteristics of a property and determine if it meets the criteria for being considered complex. This information will also provide guidance for the team when making decisions about requesting higher fees for appraisal services, helping to ensure that the fees charged are reasonable and justified.

By establishing clear and objective guidelines for determining complexity, your team will be able to provide more accurate appraisals, reduce the risk of errors or misunderstandings, and maintain the confidence of your lender clients. Additionally, this information can also be used to improve your internal processes and training programs, helping to ensure that your team is well-equipped to handle the demands of the appraisal process and provide high-quality services to your clients.
